qas.question: What are factors that determine shaft torque?

answers.text: torque current), voltage, pole-pair number, excitation frequency (i.e., synchronous speed), and air-gap flux density

qas.question: Whate decides the size of an electromagnetic core?

answers.text: air-gap area with winding slots and back-iron depth
magnetic core saturation or safe operating temperature rise and voltage

qas.question: What aren't factors that determine shaft torque?

plausible_answers.text: air-gap area with winding slots and back-iron depth

qas.question: Whate decides the size of a nonelectromagnetic core?

context: When optimally designed within a given core saturation constraint and for a given active current (i.e., <a0_0>torque current), <b3_0>voltage, pole-pair number, excitation frequency<b3_0/> (i.e., synchronous speed), and air-gap flux density<a0_0/>, all categories of electric motors or generators will exhibit virtually the same maximum continuous shaft torque (i.e., operating torque) within a given <a1_0><b4_0>air-gap area with winding slots and back-iron depth<b4_0/><a1_0/>, which determines the physical size of electromagnetic core. Some applications require bursts of torque beyond the maximum operating torque, such as short bursts of torque to accelerate an electric vehicle from standstill. Always limited by <a2_0>magnetic core saturation or safe operating <b5_0>temperature rise and voltage<b5_0/><a2_0/>, the capacity for torque bursts beyond the maximum operating torque differs significantly between categories of electric motors or generators.
